revision.text:
{{Infobox book | name = A Universe from Nothing: Why There Is Something Rather than Nothing | image = AUFN LawrenceKrauss.jpeg | caption = Softcover edition | author = [[Lawrence M. Krauss]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | series = | subject = [[Physics]]
[[Cosmology]] | publisher = [[Free Press (publisher)|Free Press]] | pub_date = January 10, 2012 | english_pub_date = | media_type = Print ([[Hardcover]] and [[Softcover]]), e-book | pages = 224 pp | isbn = 978-1-4516-2445-8 | oclc = | dewey = 523.1/8 | congress = QB981 .K773 2012 | preceded_by = [[Quantum Man: Richard Feynman's Life in Science|Quantum Man]] | followed_by = [[The Greatest Story Ever Told—So Far]] }} '''''A Universe from Nothing: Why There Is Something Rather than Nothing''''' is a non-fiction book by the physicist [[Lawrence M. Krauss]], initially published on January 10, 2012 by [[Free Press (publisher)|Free Press]]. It discusses modern [[cosmogony]] and its implications for the debate about the [[existence of God]]. The main theme of the book is how "we have discovered that all signs suggest a universe that could and plausibly did arise from a deeper [[nothing]]—involving the absence of [[space-time|space]] itself and— which may one day return to nothing via processes that may not only be comprehensible but also processes that do not require any external control or direction."{{cite web|last1=Reynosa|first1=Peter|title=Some of the Changes Lawrence M. Krauss Should Make to the Second Edition of "A Universe From Nothing"|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/peter-reynosa/some-of-the-changes-lawre_b_9664630.html|publisher=[[Huffington Post]]|accessdate=April 13, 2016}}{{cite book|last1=Krauss|first1=Lawrence M.|title=A Universe from Nothing: Why There Is Something Rather Than Nothing|date=2012|publisher=Free Press|location=New York|isbn=978-1-4516-2445-8|page=183}} == Publication == The book ends with an afterword by [[Richard Dawkins]] in which he compares the potential impact of the book to that of ''[[The Origin of Species]]'' — a comparison that Krauss himself called "pretentious".{{cite web|last=Andersen|first=Ross|title=Has Physics Made Philosophy and Religion Obsolete?|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2012/04/has-physics-made-philosophy-and-religion-obsolete/256203/|publisher=theatlantic.com|accessdate=4 March 2014}} [[Christopher Hitchens]] had agreed to write a foreword for the book prior to his death but was too ill to complete it.{{cite web|last=Krauss |first=Lawrence |title=Afterword from Lawrence Krauss' New Book – A Universe From Nothing |url=http://old.richarddawkins.net/articles/644421-afterword-from-lawrence-krauss-new-book-a-universe-from-nothing |work=excerpt |publisher=richarddawkins.net |accessdate=11 February 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130221051332/http://old.richarddawkins.net/articles/644421-afterword-from-lawrence-krauss-new-book-a-universe-from-nothing |archivedate=21 February 2013 }} To write the book, Krauss expanded material from a lecture on the cosmological implications of a [[flat expanding universe]] he gave to the [[Richard Dawkins Foundation]] at the 2009 [[Atheist Alliance International]] conference.Lawrence Krauss's 2009 lecture [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7ImvlS8PLIo A Universe from Nothing] The book appeared on ''The New York Times'' [[The New York Times bestseller list|bestseller list]] on January 29, 2012.{{cite news|title=Non Fiction Best Sellers|url=https://www.nytimes.com/best-sellers-books/2012-01-29/hardcover-nonfiction/list.html|accessdate=11 February 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=January 29, 2012}} == Reception == In the ''[[The New York Times|New York Times]]'', philosopher of science and physicist [[David Albert]] said the book failed to live up to its title; he claimed Krauss dismissed concerns about what Albert calls his misuse of the term ''nothing''.{{cite news |last=Albert |first=David |title=On the Origin of Everything |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/03/25/books/review/a-universe-from-nothing-by-lawrence-m-krauss.html |accessdate=25 April 2012 |newspaper=The New York Times Sunday Book Review |date=25 March 2012}} [[Caleb Scharf]], writing in ''[[Nature (journal)|Nature]]'', said that "it would be easy for this remarkable story to revel in self-congratulation, but Krauss steers it soberly and with grace".{{cite journal|last1=Scharf|first1=Caleb|title=Cosmology: Plucked from the vacuum|journal=Nature|date=25 January 2012|volume=481|issue=7382|pages=440–440|doi=10.1038/481440a|bibcode = 2012Natur.481..440S }} [[Ray Jayawardhana]], Canada Research Chair in observational astrophysics at the University of Toronto, wrote for ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'' that Kraus "delivers a spirited, fast-paced romp through modern cosmology and its strong underpinnings in astronomical observations and particle physics theory" and that he "makes a persuasive case that the ultimate question of cosmic origin – how something, namely the universe, could arise from nothing – belongs in the realm of science rather than theology or philosophy".{{cite news|work=The Globe and Mail|last=Jayawardhana|first=Ray|date=17 February 2012|title=A Universe From Nothing, by Lawrence Krauss|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/arts/books-and-media/a-universe-from-nothing-by-lawrence-krauss/article548906/|accessdate=21 June 2018}} In ''[[New Scientist]]'', [[Michael Brooks (science writer)|Michael Brooks]] wrote, "Krauss will be preaching only to the converted. That said, we should be happy to be preached to so intelligently. The same can't be said about the Dawkins afterword, which is both superfluous and silly."{{cite journal|last=Brooks|first=Michael|title=The paradox of nothing|journal=[[New Scientist]]|date=14 January 2012|volume=213|issue=2847}} Commenting on the philosophical debate sparked by the book, the physicist [[Sean M. Carroll]] asked, "Do advances in modern physics and cosmology help us address these underlying questions, of why there is something called the universe at all, and why there are things called '[[Physical law|the laws of physics]],' and why those laws seem to take the form of [[quantum mechanics]], and why some particular [[wave function]] and [[Hamiltonian (quantum mechanics)|Hamiltonian]]? In a word: no. I don't see how they could."{{cite web|url=http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/cosmicvariance/2012/04/28/a-universe-from-nothing/ |title=A Universe from Nothing? - Cosmic Variance : Cosmic Variance |publisher=Blogs.discovermagazine.com |date=April 28, 2012 |accessdate=April 9, 2015}} ==See also== * [[Problem of why there is anything at all]] * [[Quantum fluctuation]] == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == External links == * {{Official website|http://krauss.faculty.asu.edu/books/a-universe-from-nothing/}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Universe from Nothing}} [[Category:2012 non-fiction books]] [[Category:Popular science books]] [[Category:Physics books]] [[Category:Astronomy books]] [[Category:Physical cosmology]] [[Category:Cosmology books]] [[Category:Books by Lawrence M. Krauss]] [[Category:Cosmogony]]

revision.comment: /* Affective reaction */[[User:JCW-CleanerBot#Logic|task]], replaced: Journal of Experimental Psychology: Learning, Memory and Cognition → Journal of Experimental Psychology: Learning, Memory, and Cognition
revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=July 2018}}
In [[cognitive psychology]] the '''affect-as-information hypothesis''', or ‘approach’ is a model of evaluative processing, postulating that affective [[feeling]]s provide a source of information about objects, tasks, and decision alternatives.<ref name=":0">{{cite journal|last1=Storbeck|first1=Justin|last2=Clore|first2=Gerald L.|date=September 2008|title=Affective Arousal as Information: How Affective Arousal Influences Judgments, Learning, and Memory|journal=Social and Personality Psychology Compass|volume=2|issue=5|pages=1824–1843|doi=10.1111/j.1751-9004.2008.00138.x|pmid=25067943|pmc=4110743}}</ref><ref name=":1">Clore, G. L., & Storbeck, J. (2006). Affect as information about liking, efficacy, and importance. In J. P. Forgas & J. P. Forgas (Eds.), Affect in social thinking and behavior. (pp. 123-141). New York, NY, US: Psychology Press.</ref> A goal of this approach is to understand the extent of influence that [[Affect (psychology)|affect]] has on cognitive functioning.<ref name=":0" /> It has been proposed that affect has two major dimensions, namely affective [[Valence (psychology)|valence]] and affective arousal,<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> and in this way is an embodied source of information.<ref name=":0" /> Affect is thought to impact three main cognitive functions: [[judgement]], thought processing and [[memory]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> In a variety of scenarios, the influence of affect on these processes is thought to be mediated by its effects on [[attention]].<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":4">{{cite journal|last1=Zadra|first1=Jonathan R.|last2=Clore|first2=Gerald L.|date=11 July 2011|title=Emotion and perception: the role of affective information|journal=Wiley Interdisciplinary Reviews: Cognitive Science|volume=2|issue=6|pages=676–685|doi=10.1002/wcs.147|pmid=22039565|pmc=3203022|issn=1939-5078}}</ref> The approach is thought to account for a wide variety of behavioural phenomena in psychology.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Forgas |first1=edited by Joseph P. |title=Handbook of affect and social cognition |date=2001 |publisher=L. Erlbaum Associates |location=Mahwah, N.J. |isbn=9780585350660}}</ref>
==Informative functions of affect: reaction vs. arousal==
The affect as information hypothesis emphasises significance of the information that affect communicates, rather than the affective feelings themselves.<ref name=":1" /> Affective reactions or ‘responses’ provide an embodied source of information about ‘value’ or valence, as well as affective arousal provides an embodied source of information about importance.<ref name=":1" /> More specifically, affective reactions are pleasant or unpleasant reactions that provide information on positive (‘good’) and negative (‘bad’) value, respectively.<ref name=":0" /> Objects, task situations, and other stimuli or targets- if experienced as the source of an affective reaction- take on the positive or negative affect value.<ref name=":0" /> Affective arousal involves implicit (stress hormonal response such as from the [[adrenergic system]]) or explicit responses (subjective experience)<ref name=":1" /> that provide information on relevance, urgency, or importance.<ref name=":0" /> Both dimensions are thought to effect cognitive functioning through influencing judgements and decision making, processing, and memory,<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> and in a variety of situations this is thought to be mediated through its influences on attention.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":4" />
==Affect on judgement and decision making== ===Affective reaction=== A finding by Schwarz and Clore (1988) has been noted in literature (for example,<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":3" />), wherein individuals are thought to review and attend to their affective reactions when making evaluative judgements and decisions. They typically ask themselves, “How do I feel about it”.<ref>Schwarz, N., & Clore, G. L. (1988). How do I feel about it? Informative functions of affective states. In K. Fiedler & J. Forgas (Eds.), Affect, cognition, and social behavior (pp. 44-62). Toronto: Hogrefe International.</ref> A broad example of this (which may be applied to a variety of situations) is when considering how much we like something. Our judgements are based on how we feel about a particular stimulus as opposed to the attributes or characteristics of the said stimulus.<ref name=":3">Schwarz, N., & Clore, G. L. (2007). Feelings and phenomenal experiences. In A. W. Kruglanski, E. T. Higgins, A. W. Kruglanski, E. T. Higgins (Eds.) , Social psychology: Handbook of basic principles (pp. 385-407). New York, NY, US: Guilford Press.</ref> Essentially, if the object, task situation, or other stimulus is experienced as the source of an affective reaction and takes on the affect value, then a judgement or decision may be made about the stimulus based on these attributed feelings.<ref name=":0" /> Positive and negative affect typically lead to positive and negative judgements, respectively.<ref name=":0" />
===Affective arousal=== Affective arousal is thought to intensify positive and negative affective reactions and, as a result, judgemental evaluations- as if relying on affective arousal to indicate how strongly one feels about something.<ref name=":0" /> An empirical example of this is findings of intensified evaluations under high affective arousal when watching advertisements.<ref name=":5">{{cite journal |last1=Gorn |first1=Gerald |last2=Tuan Pham |first2=Michel |last3=Yatming Sin |first3=Leo |title=When Arousal Influences Ad Evaluation and Valence Does Not (and Vice Versa) |journal=Journal of Consumer Psychology |date=January 2001 |volume=11 |issue=1 |pages=43–55 |doi=10.1207/S15327663JCP1101_4|citeseerx=10.1.1.558.636 }}</ref> Advertisements with positive and negative affective tone were evaluated as more positive and negative respectively, under conditions of high affective arousal relative to under conditions of low affective arousal.<ref name=":5" />
===Attribution of affect=== Affect may be elicited by the stimulus or situation of relevance, which is referred to as integral affect.<ref name=":3" /> Conversely, affect may be momentary and coincide in time with the presence of the relevant stimulus, but be unrelated to the stimulus. This is referred to as incidental affect. Integral affect provides meaningful, relevant information about a target stimulus on which a judgement or decision can be made. Incidental affect may lead to affective feelings being subsequently mis-attributed to the stimulus at hand and thus provide mistaken information about the stimulus, from which a mislead judgement or decision is formed.<ref name=":3" />
===Research examples=== There is a variety of research investigating the influence of affect on judgement, and the misattribution of affect. One study in the area investigated affective valence.<ref name=":2" /> They induced positive and negative affective states based on a life event (happy versus sad), and the weather (sunny versus rainy). Induced positive affective states (good experiences, sunny weather) lead to more positive evaluations of ratings of general well-being, relative to in an induced negative affective state (sad experiences, rainy weather), which lead to more negative life evaluations. They also found that negative life evaluations from an induced negative affective state was removed when the state was induced to be attributed to an irrelevant source (not to life satisfaction). This misattribution did not occur when in an induced positive affective state. Their conclusion was that the results indicate that affective state indirectly influenced judgements of life satisfaction through the type of information conveyed by affective feelings associated with life satisfaction.<ref name=":2">{{cite journal |last1=Schwarz |first1=Norbert |last2=Clore |first2=Gerald L. |title=Mood, misattribution, and judgments of well-being: Informative and directive functions of affective states |journal=Journal of Personality and Social Psychology |date=1983 |volume=45 |issue=3 |pages=513–523 |doi=10.1037/0022-3514.45.3.513 |issn=0022-3514}}</ref>
Another study in the area illustrates misattribution, and an effect of affective arousal on judgement.<ref name=":6">{{cite journal |last1=Dutton |first1=Donald G. |last2=Aron |first2=Arthur P. |title=Some evidence for heightened sexual attraction under conditions of high anxiety |journal=Journal of Personality and Social Psychology |date=1974 |volume=30 |issue=4 |pages=510–517 |doi=10.1037/h0037031 |language=en |issn=1939-1315|citeseerx=10.1.1.335.100 }}</ref> They induced high affective arousal in the experimental condition where participants had to cross a high bridge, and a low affective arousal state in the control condition where participants had to cross a low bridge. All participants were male, and met an attractive female demonstrator on the other side of the bridge. They found that participants in the induced high affective arousal condition contacted the attractive demonstrator after the experiment significantly more than those in the induced low affective arousal condition. Males with a high affective arousal state had amplified attraction to the woman, as they misattributed their feelings of arousal caused by the bridge, to feelings of affective arousal caused by the attractive woman.<ref name=":6" />
==Affect on cognitive processing== Affect has been indicated to provide information about how benign versus problematic a situation or task is,<ref name=":3" /> which is dependent on the type of affective reaction or arousal.<ref name=":1" /> Consequently, this influences the type of information processing style that is used to interpret the situation.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":3" /> ===Affective reaction=== If the affect is attributed as a response to a situation or stimulus<ref name=":3" /> then positive affect signals a benign situation<ref name=":1" /> that promotes relational processing<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> which involves primarily [[Top-down and bottom-up design|top down]] processing of information.<ref name=":7">Clore, G. L., Wyer, R. J., Dienes, B., Gasper, K., Gohm, C., & Isbell, L. (2001). Affective feelings as feedback: Some cognitive consequences. In L. L. Martin, G. L. Clore, L. L. Martin, G. L. Clore (Eds.) , Theories of mood and cognition: A user's guidebook (pp. 27-62). Mahwah, NJ, US: Lawrence Erlbaum Associates Publishers.</ref> Conversely, negative affect signals a problematic situation,<ref name=":1" /> inhibiting processing associated with positive affect<ref name=":0" /> and promoting referential processing<ref name=":1" /> which is associated primarily with [[Top-down and bottom-up design|bottom up]] processing.<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":7" />
====Global vs. local processing==== An example of the influence of affect on processing style is that of its influence on the use of a global versus a local focus.<ref name=":1" /> Positive affect is thought to induce a more [[Global precedence|global processing]] style (processing of wholes).<ref name=":4" /> Conversely, negative affect reduces global processing and enhances a more local processing style (processing of parts or details).<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Gasper|first1=Karen|date=April 2004|title=Do you see what I see? Affect and visual information processing|journal=Cognition & Emotion|volume=18|issue=3|pages=405–421|doi=10.1080/02699930341000068|issn=0269-9931}}</ref>
Other research in this area has illustrated that the informative influence of affective valence is dependent on the accessibility of these global and local processing styles. In situations when either a global or local style was more accessible, positive affect lead to a greater increase in global or local processing respectively, compared to negative affect.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Huntsinger |first1=Jeffrey R. |last2=Clore |first2=Gerald L. |last3=Bar-Anan |first3=Yoav |title=Mood and global–local focus: Priming a local focus reverses the link between mood and global–local processing |journal=Emotion |date=2010 |volume=10 |issue=5 |pages=722–726 |doi=10.1037/a0019356|pmid=21038956 }}</ref>
====Stereotypical thought processing==== Affective valence has also been indicated to have informative effects on [[Stereotype|stereotypical]] thought processing.<ref name=":1" /> Positive affect is thought to lead to increased stereotypical thought processing, illustrated in research where participants in an induced positive mood were more likely than those in an induced neutral mood<ref name=":8">{{cite journal |last1=Bodenhausen |first1=Galen V. |last2=Kramer |first2=Geoffrey P. |last3=Süsser |first3=Karin |title=Happiness and stereotypic thinking in social judgment |journal=Journal of Personality and Social Psychology |date=1994 |volume=66 |issue=4 |pages=621–632 |doi=10.1037/0022-3514.66.4.621 |language=en |issn=0022-3514}}</ref> or negative mood <ref name=":8" /><ref name=":9" /> to make a stereotypical judgement. This was suggested to be due to stereotypical thought elicited from the positive affect.<ref name=":8" /> Additionally, negative affect has been demonstrated to lead to decreased stereotypical thought processing.<ref name=":9">{{cite journal |last1=Park |first1=J |last2=Banaji |first2=MR |title=Mood and heuristics: the influence of happy and sad states on sensitivity and bias in stereotyping |journal=Journal of Personality and Social Psychology |date=June 2000 |volume=78 |issue=6 |pages=1005–23 |pmid=10870905}}</ref>
===Affective arousal=== As in the effect of arousal in judgement, affective arousal is proposed to intensify cognitive processing that has been induced as a result of information provided by affective valence.<ref name=":0" /> An illustration is that empirical research on false memories showed with high affective arousal, more false memories were produced within different valence conditions (positive, negative, neutral) than with low affective arousal.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Corson |first1=Y |last2=Verrier |first2=N |title=Emotions and false memories: valence or arousal? |journal=Psychological Science |date=March 2007 |volume=18 |issue=3 |pages=208–11 |pmid=17444912|doi=10.1111/j.1467-9280.2007.01874.x }}</ref>
==Affect on memory== ===Affective reaction=== Affective arousal has predominantly been discussed with regard to the informative influence of affect on memory. However, the influence of affective valence on memory has been demonstrated in research, such as at [[memory retrieval]].<ref name=":10">{{cite journal |last1=Ehrlichman |first1=H |last2=Halpern |first2=JN |title=Affect and memory: effects of pleasant and unpleasant odors on retrieval of happy and unhappy memories |journal=Journal of Personality and Social Psychology |date=November 1988 |volume=55 |issue=5 |pages=769–79 |pmid=3210144}}</ref> It was illustrated that after exposure to pleasant or unpleasant odours to induce positive or negative affective valence respectively, those with induced positive affect provided significantly more positive ratings (rated as happy memory) of a retrieved memory than those with induced negative affect.<ref name=":10" /> Affective valence has also been implicated at memory [[Encoding (memory)|encoding]].<ref name=":11">{{cite journal |last1=Bradley |first1=MM |last2=Greenwald |first2=MK |last3=Petry |first3=MC |last4=Lang |first4=PJ |title=Remembering pictures: pleasure and arousal in memory |journal=Journal of Experimental Psychology: Learning, Memory, and Cognition |date=March 1992 |volume=18 |issue=2 |pages=379–90 |pmid=1532823}}</ref>
===Affective arousal=== Affective arousal has been indicated to influence memory<ref name=":0" /> as it redirects or narrows attention towards potentially important or salient factors such as environmental stimuli,<ref name=":1" /> thus influencing what information gets encoded in to memory.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":12" /> As mentioned, this effect is mediated by implicit and explicit affective arousal responses, indicative of the level of importance in a situation.<ref name=":1" /> Affective arousal has also been implicated in consolidation of [[long-term memory]] through the mediating effects of stress hormones of the adrenergic system on the [[amygdala]]- whose functions include [[memory consolidation]].<ref name=":12">{{cite journal |last1=Hamann |first1=S |title=Cognitive and neural mechanisms of emotional memory |journal=Trends in Cognitive Sciences |date=1 September 2001 |volume=5 |issue=9 |pages=394–400 |pmid=11520704}}</ref>
===Research example=== Empirical research investigating both affective valence and arousal found effects on different aspects of memory.<ref name=":11" /> In their research, they investigated the effect of induced positive versus negative affective valence, and induced high and low arousal on memory encoding using picture slides, in a delayed (to assess long-term memory) and immediate free-recall task. In both free recall conditions, high arousal at encoding lead to better memory performance than low arousal at encoding. A similar finding occurred for affective valence where positive affect at encoding lead to better memory performance, however only for the immediate free-recall condition. They concluded that their results indicate the influence of both dimensions of affect at encoding, and involvement of affective arousal in long-term memory.<ref name=":11" />
==History== ===Development of the early theory=== A researcher in the field of cognitive psychology by the name of [[Norbert Schwarz]] was interested in the informative function of feelings.<ref name=":13">Schwarz, N. (2012). Feelings-as-information theory. In P. M. Van Lange, A. W. Kruglanski, E. T. Higgins, P. M. Van Lange, A. W. Kruglanski, E. T. Higgins (Eds.) , Handbook of theories of social psychology (pp. 289-308). Thousand Oaks, CA: Sage Publications Ltd. doi:10.4135/9781446249215.n15</ref> He commenced research alongside Robert Wyer and Gerald Clore. Building off the ideas of earlier works, one he summarised was that current feelings elicited increase the availability of information congruent with that feeling.<ref name=":13" /> He recognised that these ideas were developed upon by the earlier researchers; Isen, Shalker, Clark, and Karp (1978),<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Isen |first1=AM |last2=Shalker |first2=TE |last3=Clark |first3=M |last4=Karp |first4=L |title=Affect, accessibility of material in memory, and behavior: a cognitive loop? |journal=Journal of Personality and Social Psychology |date=January 1978 |volume=36 |issue=1 |pages=1–12 |pmid=621625}}</ref> and Bower (1981),<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Bower |first1=GH |title=Mood and memory |journal=The American Psychologist |date=February 1981 |volume=36 |issue=2 |pages=129–48 |pmid=7224324}}</ref> who were researching affect and cognitive functioning. Additionally, the influential idea in this field stemming from the work of Wyer and Carlston (1979)<ref>Wyer, R.S. & Carlston, D.E. (1979). Social cognition, inference, and attribution. Hillsdale, NJ: Erlbaum.</ref> was that a function of affect is to provide information about a target. Their investigation into the functions of feelings gave further insight into the informative functions of feelings, from which they derived core postulates of their theory.<ref name=":13" /> Development of the theory and postulates derived are detailed and summarised in Schwarz’s (2010) ‘Feelings as information theory’.<ref name=":13" />
== References == <!-- Inline citations added to your article will automatically display here. See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WP:REFB for instructions on how to add citations. --> {{reflist}}
[[Category:Psychological theories]]
